direction.raw_text: Framed in the large picture window stands JACK CARTER, alone, looking out at the night. He turns away as the heavy satin curtains close, wiping him from view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A blinding beam of light cuts across the room. One pornographic slide after another hits the screen at the opposite end of the room. They show a dowdy group in some anonymous bedroom, frozen in various stages of a sexual orgy. GERALD FLETCHER is slumped on a sofa. His young wife, ANNA, is curled up beside him. SID FLETCHER, operating the projector's remote-control, has the same flaccid appearance as his twin brother. Jack Carter, drink in hand, watches from an armchair. Clunk. Another slide hits the screen. Gerald is getting turned on. He runs his hand along his wife's stockinged leg. Anna shudders momentarily. She obviously finds his touch repulsive. Carter watches Gerald's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter turns sharply away to the cocktail cabinet. Lights and sweet music happen when he opens it. Clunk. The slide changes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still looking at the screen, Gerald continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack and Anna look at each other momentarily. There is definitely something between them. JACK No. Clunk. The slide changes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (removing the cigar from his mouth) Bollock naked with his socks still on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thoughtfully) They do that up North.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for? Protective purposes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ask me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ask Jack. It's his old stamping ground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Must be a bloody contortionist
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't want you to go up the North, Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (groans) Not suede boots! SID Knock it off, Gerald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? And get the clap? Clunk. The slide changes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You work for us, Jack. We have connections in those parts.  I'd hate you to screw 'em up. Clunk. The slide changes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that? A python. Sid laughs raucously.  Clunk. The slide changes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going for? JACK To find out what happened. Clunk. The slide changes. GERALD Some hard nuts operate up there, Jack. They won't take kindly to someone from London poking his bugle in. JACK Too bad. GERALD I smell trouble, boy. Clunk. The slide changes. SID The law was satisfied. JACK Since when was that good enough? Clunk. The slide changes. GERALD Think again, Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Express train plunges into a tunnel Blackness. BEGIN TITLES:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The compartment is full. Jack Carter sits in one corner, reading a Raymond Chandler paperback, Farewell My Lovely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train speeds northwards. In the distance the stacks of a lonely power station belch a continuous stream of brown smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter steadies himself as he comes along the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A massive iron bridge crossing a river whips past. Its mesh sides create an almost hypnotic effect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter tips his head back and dispenses drops into his nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train breaks from another tunnel. Evening light cuts across the track as the train hurtles on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter pours himself a glass of water and takes out a small phial of brown pills. He swallows one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A chemical factory, brightly lit, passes by and the outskirts of the city appear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train moves slowly along the platform and stops. Carter collects his coat and briefcase from the rack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The street is fairly deserted. Carter exits with other passengers from the train. He pauses and looks about before crossing to the pub opposite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A couple of youths are playing records on the juke box. An old man sits in the corner reading a newspaper. Carter enters through the swing door and a weedy BARMAN comes to serve him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The barman picks up a glass mug and begins to draw the beer. Carter snaps his fingers at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: thin glass and puts it on the counter. A telephone rings. The second barman answers it. BARMAN Is there a Mr Carter in the room? CARTER Yes. Carter walks to the far end of the bar and picks up the receiver.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pint of bitter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a thin glass. The barman sighs petulantly, transfers the beer into a
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello? (pause) Margaret? (pause) Why the hell aren't you here? (he lights a cigarette.) What time? (pause) Is Doreen at the house? (pause) Who's with him then? (pause) When can I see you? Will you be there tomorrow? (pause) Now listen, Margaret... The line goes dead. Carter hangs up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A key hanging inside the letter box starts to move upwards and out through the flap. A moment later, the door opens. Carter is standing at the bottom of a flight of stairs in a worker's terraced house. He closes the door and climbs the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter moves cautiously. His eyes scan the peeling wallpaper, the mildew on the banisters. A roof leak hits an unseen bucket with depressing regularity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An unmade bed with pyjamas on it, a beaten-up wardrobe, a dressing table and chair are about it. Carter hears a vehicle stopping on the street below. He eases back the ancient net curtain. Two men in a Land Rover are looking up. They see him and quickly drive off. Carter looks around the room. On top of the wardrobe there's an old shotgun. He reaches up and brings it down. Memories flood back. He reaches up again and finds a box of cartridges. More memories, jack and Frank grew up here. He leaves the gun on the bed and returns to the landing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pitch black. An overhead light snaps on to the face of a dead man FRANK CARTER. He is lying in a coffin. His eyes are closed, his skin made-up, like porcelain. Carter stands over the coffin. He gently touches his brother's crossed hands and folds the shroud over his face. He exits, turning out the light and closing the door. Darkness returns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The landlady, EDNA GARFOOT, is climbing the stairs. She's well built, sexy, experienced. Carter follows with his baggage. He watches her appreciatively from behind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I won't be using the room tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stops and turns) I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm staying with a friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing up the stairs) Her husband docks tomorrow, does he? CARTER (smiles) It's not like that, luv.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It never is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The door opens and the light goes on. It's a big room overlooking the road, furnished cheaply but comfortably. Edna and Carter enter, talking. EDNA Are you a traveller? CARTER (smiling) Definitely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter smiles and looks straight at her. Edna returns his look, dead pan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She closes the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (surveying the room) Will this do? CARTER (looking around) Very nice. (He takes his wallet out.) I'll pay you for tonight as well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be bloody silly. You're the first since Monday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sure? Carter gives her the money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (feeling the mattress) I'll bet this one's seen some action.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll give you the key when you come down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carter moves around the coffin as he shaves. His electric razor is plugged into the lamp above his dead brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The coffin lid is being screwed down. Carter stirs a cup of instant coffee while watching the undertakers at work. CARTER Was he in bad shape? UNDERTAKER They come worse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hearse is parked outside the row of terraced houses. A youthful UNDERTAKER is minding it. He turns and looks through the back window as a young girl walks up the street. DOREEN CARTER is sixteen and, like most girls of her age, tries to look older. She wears all the right gear but it's cheap and doesn't fit properly. Her long hair is lank. There's something sad and embarrassing about her appearance. The young undertaker watches as she enters Frank's house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens slowly. Doreen stands there looking at the coffin. Carter sees her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: screw into the coffin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Doreen? She seems mesmerized by what's going on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, are you? Doreen doesn 't answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Been staying with a friend? Doreen nods. The undertaker coughs and thrusts another
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry about your father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me, Doreen, did the police say anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dazed) They said he was drunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The young undertaker is still in the hearse listening to the radio. In the driving mirror he sees the Land Rover moving slowly tip the road. It stops by the house. Two men suss the scene and drive off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's school? DOREEN I left last year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter and Doreen look at each other awkwardly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doreen looks at him nervously, shakes her head and fumbles in her bag for a cigarette. Carter continues, slightly indignant.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, what you doing now? DOREEN Working at Woolworths. CARTER That must be interesting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you going to do? Live with Margaret?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, why won't you come with us to South America? My fiancee won't mind, (pause) Your dad would have wanted it. The undertaker puts the final screw in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to colleague) Get Hughbert up, will you? (to Carter) We're ready now, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The undertakers struggle with the coffin down the narrow staircase into the street. Outside Carter and Doreen wait with two men. EDDIE APPLEYARD, a middle-aged man, is wearing a shabby tweed suit, cap and black tie. KEITH LACEY is a young barman who worked with Frank.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We weren't sure where it was taking place, like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice of you to come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Frank was a good bloke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Through the windscreen of the following limousine Carter can see his brother's coffin in the hearse as it moves slowly through the streets of the city. Sitting in front on fold-out seats are Eddie and Keith.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't believe it when I heard. Carter is suddenly attentive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? KEITH I mean, I was surprised when he didn't turn up for work.  He was always on time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you work with him, Keith? KEITH At the Half Moon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not to be left out) It's a bloody funny thing. You know a bloke for six bloody years and all the time he's as calm as gentle Jesus... (pause) ...then he goes and does a thing like that. (he shakes his head.) It's a bloody funny thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Yeah. A bloody funny thing!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the cortege drives into the crematorium, it passes the Land Rover parked outside. The same two men who passed Frank's house are in it. A long and expensive-looking funeral cortege passes out as they move up the driveway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter, Doreen, Eddie and Keith are in the front pews facing the catafalque on which Frank's coffin rests. The vicar is already midway through the solemn words of the 'committal' when a woman enters. The clunk of her high heels cuts through the silence. Everybody looks round.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering to Doreen) Is that Margaret? Doreen nods. Frank's coffin sinks out of sight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two men in long grey coats wait in silence. The coffin appears. Expertly, they take it and swing it on to a trolley. They push it up the wide corridor towards the furnace. One of the men starts whistling cheerfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is thirtyish, blonde, attractive in a tarty kind of way.  Her heels are too high and she is wearing a cheap pair of sunglasses. She walks quickly away, down the cloisters, past the memorial tablets and urns. Carter comes out of the chapel and sees her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Margaret stops and looks round. Carter joins her.  I thought you weren't coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They face each other in silence. Margaret looks past Carter and sees Doreen watching them at the end of the cloisters. She turns away and starts walking slowly. Carter moves with her.  Margaret continues nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Margaret stops in her tracks and looks back at Doreen. She's still watching them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Margaret starts walking again, fast. Carter catches hold of her arm and stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves off rapidly. Carter catches up with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Margaret walks off as calmly as she can, her high heels clicking as she goes. Carter watches her disappear. Doreen watches too.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Margaret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Changed me mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyhing go off all right? CARTER Fine... (pause) I want to talk to you. MARGARET What about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doreen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (adamantly) She's nothing to do with me. CARTER (puzzled) What do you mean? You've been Frank's bird ever since her mother cleared off. You're closer to her than anyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking her head) No. No. It's not like that. I've got a husband, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold it!   Hold it! (looking her in the eye) Who killed Frank, Margaret?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervously) Killed?  I don't know anything about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must go. I'm in a hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to talk to you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow morning, then? Margaret dithers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, all right then. Twelve o'clock on the Iron Bridge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frank's coffin is slid inside the furnace. Flames start to lick it as the steel trap closes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a large room with a horseshoe bar in the centre, a real boozer.  A handful of hard drinkers are already in position. Carter, Doreen, Keith and Eddie are sitting alone. Their table is already covered with glasses. Doreen appears to be slightly drunk on Babycham, Eddie on whisky and Keith on beer. Carter is stone-cold sober.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doreen watches them. She is getting very upset by the conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doreen is now crying openly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She runs off out of the door crying. Keith goes to follow. Carter puts his hand out to restrain him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie stands up, cap in hand. Carter pulls out a wad of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eddie leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter thinks for a moment, then leans forward to Keith. CARTER Keith, if anybody comes in here and asks for me, you let me know. Right? KEITH Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter takes out his phial of pills.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Absent friends. (He raises his glass and drinks, then continues thoughtfully.) You don't think he might have done it on purpose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? You mean, like, kill himself? Eddie and Keith look at each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naw. Frank? Kill himself? You what? Carter stares at Keith, who is getting uncomfortable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, what for? CARTER That's what I was wondering.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come off it. Frank was... well... straight. He had no worries I know. Hell, we worked together every day for a year. It would have showed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would it? KEITH It just would. He was always the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since when did he drink whisky? KEITH Don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody seems to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finishing off his drink) Bloody good bloke. One of the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blurts out) How would you know? (She suddenly jumps up and empties her glass in Eddie's face.) Or you?  Or you? None of you knew. I knew. He was me dad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let her go. She'll be OK. (to Eddie) Sorry about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wiping his face with a handkerchief) Don't worry. She's bound to be upset.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Eddie) Have another? EDDIE No. I'll be off now. I should be at work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, look. (He peels off a note.) Get your suit cleaned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. It's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (standing, pushes the note in his top pocket) Thanks for coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frank was a good bloke. It's the least I could have done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You work here, Keith? KEITH Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm at the Las Vegas. Behind the dance hall. (He casts an eye around the bar.) Do you know a man called Albert Swift?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. He comes in here a bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where would I find him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Today? At the races. He always goes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you know Albert?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Went to school with him. (smiles) He was leader of our gang. He'll know what's going on in this town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The rain has just stopped. Bookies and punters lower their umbrellas. Horses thunder towards the finishing post. Turf flies in all directions as the jockeys whip their mounts in a last desperate effort and the crowd roars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albert Swift is standing by a bookmaker's marking bis race card with a biro. A hot dog is sticking out of his mouth, like a cigar. A man of about thirty-five, be appears much older, probably from an excess of booze and women. He looks up, and his mouth drops open, the hot dog falling to the ground. He has seen Carter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter is pushing his way along the line of bookies, all the time looking about him. The track loudspeaker announces the winner of the last race.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albert pales. He holds his race card in front of his face and disappears into the crowd. As he moves off, his foot steps on the hot dog and tomato ketchup oozes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter stands alone, casting an eye over the punters. His eyes rest on someone the other side of the saddling ring ERIC PAICE.  Dressed in a grey chauffeur's uniform, cap, dark glasses and gloves, he is standing close to three well-heeled-looking men with binoculars and shooting sticks. Horses for the next race are being led around the enclosure. Carter approaches from behind. He looks at Eric closely before speaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric swings round, startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter takes out his cigarettes. Eric takes one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter flicks bis lighter and gives Eric a, light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric smiles back. CARTER Brumby? Eric shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric shakes his head
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A track announcement interrupts them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter looks across at the track.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Grey suits you, Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack Carter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amused) Eric. Eric Paice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you doing around here then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you know this is my home town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I didn't know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Funny, that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. So what're you doing? On your holidays?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I'm visiting relatives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It would be. If they were still living.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Meaning what? CARTER A bereavement. A death in the family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right, Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, well. Small world, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very... (pause) So, who you working for these days Eric?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm straight. (indicating uniform) Respectable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) What are you doing? Advertising Martini?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you've been watching television.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, (pause) Come off it, Eric. Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kinnear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's it to you anyway? CARTER I've always ad your welfare at heart, Eric. Besides which, I'm nosy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not always a healthy way to be...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you should know, if I remember rightly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you're doing all right then, Eric. You're making good. ERIC Making a living.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good prospects for advancement, is there? A pension? (He can't resist it any longer. He lifts the sunglasses off Eric's nose and looks into his eyes.) Do you know, I'd almost forgotten what your eyes looked like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're still the same. Piss holes in the snow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still got a sense of humour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I retained that, Eric. (He moves towards the saddling ring and turns to Eric.) Do you know a man called Albert Swift, Eric?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't say I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't miss the start on my account.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Starting gates slam open and the horses leap out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter is driving along a country road. Ahead, two cars are between him and a Cadillac with dark-tinted windows. The Cadillac turns on to a minor road. Carter follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric Paice is driving. In the back sit the three men seen with him at the race track. The drinks compartment is open and they are helping themselves to champagne. Racing results come over the car radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter follows the Cadillac at a safe distance. It turns into a driveway. Carter slows down and reads a sign by the entrance: The Heights. He drives on and parks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter comes through a wooded area. He pauses by a lake, now overgrown with weeds. A big man stands tossing stones into the water. Carter silently picks up a dead branch then runs at the man. Carter whacks him on the head and he collapses unconscious into the lake. Carter moves on towards the house. MARTY and RAY the two men previously seen in the Land Rover, are playing with an Alsatian on the spacious lawn fronting the house. It's a Victorian building surrounded by acres of woodland. Carter breaks from the trees and darts for the side door. One of the men notices and shouts after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter runs into the house and slips into a small service room. Ray and then Marty charge inside but miss seeing Carter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A game of poker is in progress. Seated around the table are the three men with Eric at the race track. With them is an elegant man, CYRIL KINNEAR. On the sofa are GLENDA, a sexy-looking young woman, and Eric Paice. Ray bursts in. RAY Carter's here. Eric jumps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter walks past Ray, blowing him a kiss. Kinnear watches with some amusement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter looks at Eric.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray closes the door behind him. Glenda brings Carter his Scotch. He looks at her as she sits beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the three men sitting around the table with Kinnear gets impatient. PETER, LES AND HARRY are well-heeled, middle- aged, northern businessmen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry keeps a cold, wary eye on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry looks at his cards. Glenda tucks her legs up, making sure that Carter gets an eyeful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter looks back at the table. Kinnear pushes in some money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kinnear lays more cash on the table.

There's a party going on. Lights are on in every room and the rock music is loud. The drive is lined with sports cars. Carter parks and gets out. Out of a side door a young man stumbles towards the lily pond.  There, he promptly throws up. Carter watches from behind a tree. His attention shifts to the white Bentley turning into the drive. It brakes sharply and the driver jumps out.

Carter watches. Doreen bites her nails and looks terrified. Reflected in the mirror behind Carter is the image of Albert taking off his trousers. The reel runs out and flaps like a fish. direction.raw_text: Carter is driving along a coast road. The sea and a wide beach lie on his right. Long rows of houses are to his left. The sun is still low. It's very quiet. He arrives at a harbour and drives on until he reaches the end of a vast wooden jetty running out into the estuary. It's a coal loader for tankers. This jetty is very high, a complex of wooden staves and pillars, interwoven with steps and gangways. On its top tier is a complex of railway lines, signals and black coal chutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter parks his car and picks up the shotgun and a bottle of Scotch off the back seat. He get out and walks over to the jetty and along a lower gangway. At the far end, a man is standing. It's Eric Paice. Eric turns around abruptly. He sees Carter and disappears up the nearest stairway. Carter follows. At the top he stops to listen, but can see and hear only the harbour waters lapping below. Carter looks back to the coal jetty, just in time to see Eric scamper down to the level below. Eric sprints for the roadway. Carter waits and then starts running directly above him. Eric keeps running. Carter stays always overhead. He's playing cat and mouse with Eric.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paice darts down another staircase to ground level and makes for the roadway. Carter stops above the roadway. Below, Paice makes for the parked car. Carter holds the gun up. Eric stops and looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can see Eric scampering along the row of cottages towards the beach. Carter starts after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling out) You couldn't win an egg and spoon race, Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wheezing) Sod off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay away from the car or I'll blow you apart. Eric darts under the jetty. Carter runs on down the steps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eric runs out on to the beach. The only sounds are his feet pounding the pebbles and his hurtful panting. In the distance, factory chimneys belch out smoke.  Carter appears. For a moment he watches Eric stumbling along at the far end of the beach. He climbs down to the beach and starts running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter is gaining on Eric rapidly. Eric looks round and panics. He stumbles and falls over. He gets to his feet quickly and disappears round the headland. Carter follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the other side of the headland, the scene is extraordinary. The deserted beach is like the edge of the world. The sand is black as far as the eye can see. It's littered with rubbish. Several old lorries are sunk deep in the sand. High, grass-covered cliffs flank it on the left. It's deserted. In the distance, a continuous line of giant black buckets move, like cable-cars, out to sea, before they deposit their load of coal slag and move inland again. The coal mine itself is inland, hidden away behind the cliffs. The sea, like the sand, is black as it crashes on to the shore. Eric is half-way along the beach, struggling in the mud. Carter closes on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric nears the line of buckets and cuts inland towards the mine.  Carter has nearly caught up. The buckets grind and crash as they move along the cable. Eric scrambles up the narrow valley down which the coal slag travels. He is panting horribly. Carter is close on his heels.  Near the top, where the buckets are practically at ground level, Eric stumbles and falls. He is too exhausted to get up. Carter stands over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric just manages it. Carter pulls the bottle of Scotch out of his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric takes the cap off and looks at Carter. He's in a terrible state.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric pours the whisky into his month. It spills over and runs down his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eric begins to stagger about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: mercy there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's disgusting to watch. Suddenly, he retches, but nothing comes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter leans forward and with his free hand lifts the bottle up to Eric's mouth again. In the other, he holds the shotgun.  Eric chokes and retches. Carter has seen enough. CARTER Goodbye, Eric. Carter raises the butt of the gun and brings it down on Eric's head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (panting slightly) Stand up, Eric. Stand up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I bet you could use a drink, could you, Eric? He throws the bottle to Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eh? Have a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still got your sense of humour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drink up, Eric. Drink up. I want you to drink all of that. Do you understand? Drink up. Just like it was with my brother, Frank. Go on, son. Drink up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drink up, Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was you who poured it down him. Eh, Eric? Eric takes a breather and looks pathetically at Carter. No
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you all have a good laugh, eh? Did you have a good laugh when he was spewing it up? The whisky is pouring all over Eric's face and suit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drink it! Drink it! Did you all pass the bottle round after the car went over the top? Eric is choking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't stop, Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eric's body, loaded on to a a coal bucket, moves off on it's final journey. Carter, laughing, walks beside it, gun riding on his shoulder. The bucket shudders and grinds as it moves along the cable. Eric's body moves of on its final journey. It reaches the end of the line, where an automatic catch tilts it. Eric's body drops into the sea. The coal slag follows in a cloud of black dust. The waves pass over and everything is gone. Carter stands for a moment, turns and walks back along the beach. He stops, looks at the shotgun, and decides to get rid of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Below, Carter moves slowly by the edge of the sea. He raises the shotgun to throw it away. High on the clifftop a rifle and telescopic lens line up on Carter. A finger curls around the trigger. On the middle finger of the same hand is a large gold ring with the letter 'J' engraved upon it. It is the man Kinnear contacted after sending Eric to his death. The finger tightens on the trigger and pulls it. There's a quiet, whooshing sound. Carter drops to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carter lies on the beach. The waves lap around his head. A small trickle of blood pours out of a hole in his temple. He's dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kinnear's hit man coolly dismantles his rifle. He carefully wraps it in a cloth fishing-rod carrier. He walks off and is soon lost as he drops out of sight.
direction.name: direction
